It's another game in the genre of "rogue lights" I guess they call them? Select a character with certain stats, your weapons fire themselves and all you do is move around. Use keyboard or controller. The graphics are basic but well made and humouristic. The stats are deep and very well thought through. Read the Brotato Wiki to get an idea. You'll be overwhelmed.
The game allows for mods too. It's fairly cheap and available on many platforms.

"Brotato" presents itself as a compact and accessible game, perfectly tailored for those moments when you're seeking a quick, entertaining diversion without the commitment required by more extensive titles. Its minimal hard drive footprint is a commendable feature, making it an easy addition to any gaming library, particularly for players with limited storage space or those who prefer a lightweight gaming experience.

At its core, "Brotato" is imbued with a fun, engaging gameplay loop that offers immediate gratification and an easy-to-pick-up structure. This aspect makes it an excellent choice for casual gaming sessions, where the aim is to unwind and enjoy without getting bogged down by complex mechanics or storylines. The game shines in its ability to deliver short bursts of enjoyment, making it a go-to for filling brief periods of free time.

However, it's worth noting that "Brotato" may not hold the attention of players looking for depth and variety in the long run. The gameplay, while initially captivating, can evolve into a repetitive cycle, potentially diminishing its appeal over extended play sessions. This repetition is a double-edged sword; on one hand, it allows for a straightforward and accessible experience, but on the other, it may lead to a sense of monotony for those seeking a more dynamic and evolving challenge.

"Brotato" stands out as a fun and enjoyable game with a specific appeal to those in search of light, engaging entertainment that doesn't demand much in terms of time or system resources. Its simplicity and ease of access are its greatest strengths, though its repetitive nature might limit its long-term appeal to some players. It's very low cost which drives the overall value up for most. Overall, it's a good choice for gamers looking for a fun, rogue like, simple game.

Road to 100%: Game #16

This game makes me feel like there's something seriously wrong with me. I enjoyed it way too much.

Brotato is literally just picking up things, choosing a few things and moving around. It's just one big math equation and some running around. The strategy is: get the green stuff and don't die so you can get more green stuff and try harder not to die. But goddammit this $4.99 game is more fun than most, to a ridiculously addicting level. I mean half the time I’m just itching to get to the line of coke that is Wave 9 and literally I'll I'm doing is picking up green shapes.

I loved how the game seemed to promote whatever build you were going for, at least with weapons; it wants you to get your Tier IV stuff, it wants you to hit that Dodge cap, it wants you to be ridiculously OP because you need to be ridiculously OP. This is a great mechanic for a roguelike, because it promotes replay ability by encouraging builds without the heavy reliance on RNG. Overall, the loot pool is exactly what it needs to be; the upgrades, the stats, they even got the rarity colors right, it's so sexy.

I think Brotato is a fantastic example of how simplicity trumps complexity! Enjoyed every minute.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that just wants something small to play and has some free time, It's pretty fun. It also has mods which make the game a lot easier (if you get the right ones) but I don't recommend using them if you want to beat the game normally. There's not really anything I dislike about the game. I also really like that there is a lock option on the shop so if you get something op but can't afford it you can save it for when you can get it in future rounds.
If your into Horse Survivor style gameplay... this is your alley, a great game with great progression. very challenging when you get into the medium to upper echelon of tiers.

Best game that has come out of the Vampire Survivor-like craze by far. It combines the gameplay of Vampire Survivors with the deckbuilding genre (think Slay the Spire or Monster Train) and its much more interesting and replayable as a result. The choices you make have a massive impact on how a run goes, which sets it apart from most Vampire Survivor-likes.

Grinding for small cumulative stat bonuses is not a thing, but there are unlocks (different items/weapons that can show up in runs as well as an absolute fuckton of different characters).
I have over 200 hours in this game across 3 platforms. I can't stop. 10/10

Game is/was too simple.  I know it's cheap, currently listed for $4.99.  And honestly, if this were on a mobile device I'd probably have a different opinion.

There isn't enough interesting progression or build options to keep players like myself interested.  The level(s) are extremely basic and there aren't any unique goals or missions to consider.  I believe modding is available so you could find some community content that really unlocks a better game experience?

In any case, the market is flooded with these types of games and if you aren't doing anything to stand out from the rest, it's hard to justify yet another purchase or time investment for more of the (almost) exact same experiences.

"Brotatoe" offers a delightful fusion of hippy culture, potato power, and laid-back gameplay. With its peaceful vibes, creative concept, and inclusive spirit, this groovy spudventure invites players to relax, unwind, and embrace the joy of gaming. As a game it continues to be clear that "Brotatoe" remains a beloved favorite among hippies and gamers alike. -hippie gamer blog

There is a lot of potential here, for things like multiplayer, game modes, maps, character combinations, etc, but none of those exist. You play the same empty map, are given the same variety of weapons, & fight the same enemies, every single game. The characters themselves do not have enough uniqueness to make each run feel different, quite a few of the rarer/legendary items almost never showed up in 20+ hours of gameplay (unless building 100-200+ luck)

Mods add a little extra, but a lot of them feel like they should have been implemented into a game (better tooltips/HUD, combining characters, multiplayer - because as mods they are broken/only half work)

So much wasted potential

While not the best in it's genre, Brotato is still an enjoyable "survivor" game and quite challenging at its higher levels. My biggest gripe with the game is that there isn't a more surefire way to build/spec your character between rounds. Most games from this genre have a "special" store, or guaranteed drops/pick-ups for certain completions or builds whereas that's not really the case with Brotato. You can't pick up or unlock weapons mid horde. As a result, a majority of the runs - despite the quite varied character selection - can feel similar if not identical in progression to wave 20 or beyond as the stores will invariably spit out the same weapons or items. This isn't to say there aren't challenge or special "Bros" you can choose from (Pacifist thrives off keeping the enemies alive, Soldier won't attack unless standing still, Sick will constantly take damage, etc.). I do believe that this game tends to feed you items/weapons parallel to your build. Nevertheless, it's definitely missing something. I think with one or two more major updates - focusing on additional weapons, more innovative ways to spend your money beyond the post level store, additional neutral spawns like the tree, and differing maps - that this game will steadily climb its way to the top. Alright on PC. Great on the Steamdeck.

One of the best implementations in the genre. 
Some very good decisions where taken while designing the game:
1) you can choose one out of dozens of characters with distinct features at the start of the run
2) you need to finish the run on the base level with each character to finish the game, but different difficulty levels are availble for each character 
3) winning the game with a character unlocks a new character, item or weapon that makes the previously mastered characters replayable or adds a new challenge
4) catchy graphics, nothing is pixelated and the game is pleasent to play. Power ups can be worn by the character and are stupidly silly which is a good thing (e.g. character running with butterfly wings) 
5) huge variety of weapons builds, categories etc.
6) the game lets you breathe during the match. Skill is required, but you do not need to focus every seond.

My wife who isn't really a avid gamer really loves the game.    This game is worth every dollar.  Thank you to XBOX gamepass for giving me a chance to play before I buy.

Unfortunatelly, I cannot recommend this game. At first, it was all fun, but when I unlocked difficulty 5 the fun stopped. I think this game is just ridiculously hard. I usually start out well, without any problems getting to wave 10 or so, but eventually around this point in the game I die and I have no idea why. It's not clear if it's for lack of damage, HP, or whatever stat. The game doesnt tell you where you went wrong, and every death of mine looks the same. I read some guides on how to be better, and so I did what they told me, yet it didn't really help. Even tho the runs dont even last for too long, and I could get what I lost in 15 minutes, I happen to rage harder than any game I played in a while. And yes, I know I don't have to play difficulty 5, but after unlocking it I don't feel like there is any point to play on lower difficulties, since I was aiming to 100% the game eventually, and that would be a waste of time. I wouldn't get the same sense of achievement anyway. And before the sweaty fans with a degree of potato science come and say "skill issue", I'm rewieving it as a guy who looked for some fun (which I also find in 100%-ing the game). Okay so, I know this review might not be relatable, in fact, it might not even make sense, but that's how I feel about the game. It hooked me for quite a decent amount of hours, but every time I leave angry. Commenting is welcome, I hope to see what you think and how you could change my mind.

The game is okay, but I didn't have fun playing it.
I really wanted to enjoy it, which is why I've played for over 80 hours and beat 2/3 of the characters on the hardest difficulty.

I liked the amount of different characters, that each offer a somewhat different playstyle
and how the game does a (mostly) good job at portraying information and explaining stats.

I disliked that my runs would mostly end in a glass cannon build, because offense is often better than defence. This also led to me dying in the second half of the run, mostly at the last wave, which is annoying.

I hated the randomness, because it kills perfectly fine runs. For example most ranged weapons have a huge benefit from the piercing ability, but there will be runs, where you just won't encounter it, which will likely kill you. Another example is, that some characters have an item that is somewhat necessary to beat a run and sometimes you just won't see it. This issue has many more iterations.

I also think the game is quite ugly.

Edit: I'm a completionist so I revisited this game to beat it. It seems better balanced now, but I still didn't really enjoy my time.

[b][h1]Brotato[/h1][/b]Brotato is a hoard roguelite shooter where you fight against waves of enemies as you buy and merge an assortment of different weapons and items to create a build to survive against the final boss of each run. Brotato went into early access around the time when bullet-heaven games were booming on steam, while this isn't directly part of that genre, my interest in brotato was due to it.

[b][h2]Gameplay[/h2][/b]You start a run by picking a character and selecting one of it's preset starting weapons. There are currently 44 unique characters you can unlock by completing missions, different characters have their own positive and negative stat changes and unique interactions that really make each one stand out. Runs are split into 20 waves; getting longer each time, killing enemies drops materials which are the currency for buying weapons and items in your run. After a wave you take a stat upgrade from level-ups and then enter the shop. In the shop you can buy up to 6 weapons and a huge number of items which effect your stats and how your weapons perform. Each wave gets progressively harder with more and different enemy types until the final wave where you have to defeat 1 of 2 final bosses or survive until the timer runs out.

There are 5 danger difficulties in Brotato, these make runs more difficult by adding new enemies, stronger enemies and 2 bosses on the final wave. There's a neat way to track your progress on which character's you have beat on which difficulties; there is a colour for every danger level and by completing a difficulty with a certain character their character selection background colour changes to match it.

[b][h2]Achievements (83/83)[/h2][/b]It's impossible to avoid the achievements in Brotato as they are heavily tied to item and character unlocks; winning a run for the first time with each character unlocks an achievement and a new item that you can find in your next runs. For the most part the achievements are just about learning the waves, what weapons/stats work well and getting good rng.

[b][h2]Settings/Accessibility/Misc[/h2][/b]By default weapons aim at the closest enemy, there are options for mouse aim and manual aim at the press of a button. You can highlight your character, weapons or enemy projectiles to make them stand out. You can even adjust enemy health, damage and speed from the settings before a run if you're struggling, or make them higher if you want even more of a challenge. The game even has steam workshop mod support, which helps tremendously in keeping the game alive long-term.
 
[b][h2]TL;DR[/h2][/b]There really is something here for all types of players, a tonne of content in weapons and characters making no 2 runs are exactly the same, Mod support expands this into infinite content/replayability. Achievements are challenging but get easier as you improve. For only £3.99 that is a bargain.

Brotato is an arena-shooter-roguelite in which you play a potato. Sounds wierd it first glance, but this game has some really neat mechanics.

[b]What I like about Brotato[/b]

- tons of characters & achievements, resulting in high replayability
- various number of possible builds caused by many characters, weapons & items
- items don't have a simple advantage, most items have a small drawback, which encourages focusing around a certain playstyle/build
- endless mode (= even more replayability)
- 6 different difficulty levels, as well as the option to make things easier/harder (this enables even the clumsiest one to get all achievements)
- satisfying sound effects and awesome music
- creative community (work shop stuff, etc.)
- frequent updates (till v.1.0, hopefully even beyond that)

[b]What I don't like about Brotato[/b]

- weapon balance could be better (e.g. SMGs are way better compared to a Revolver)
- character balance could be better (e.g. Old makes your game significantly harder)
- many enemies on the screen cause high FPS drops (especially noticable on Pacifist)

To sum up, you can't go wrong buying this game because it's so cheap and delivers a ton of fun and content (at least in my opinion). The frequent updates mean that the dev(s) actually care for their game and ensures that they (probably) won't just discontinue the game and run away with your money. The community also made some cool stuff, so if development should stop at one point in the future, the community will most likely keep this game alive.

Brotatos unite! Against evil aliens from space or something. If you ever had the urge to shoot a floating elefant-trunk-alien with a potato gun or get run over by slimy horde of purple helmet-heads, then this is the scratch for your itch. This hack-n-slash(?) features several different characters, weapons, difficulties and alien enemies to get to wave 20 and beyond. Your average Brotato can wield 6 weapons from primitive sticks to nuclear weapons, and can utilize a special set of character stats or go for the general brother-potato. During the waves, enemies and trees drop materials (and sometimes crates) to buy upgrades between the waves. The map is relatively small to master and two characters have map size altered. Options for gameplay are not just for pleasing your eye, you can change difficulty options as well. Something i learned when i had like 3 achievements left... Oh and the fisherman is the worst Brotato. Seriously useless, like the Toby of brotatoes. Anyway, the game is perfect for a little brain-turn-off, and is worthy of a sequel.

In the world of indie games, it's rare to find a gem that perfectly balances simplicity, challenge, and addictive gameplay. Brotato is one such game - a deceptively straightforward yet profoundly engaging experience.

[b]The Allure of Simplicity[/b]
As a top-down arena shooter, Brotato doesn't bog you down with complex storylines or convoluted mechanics. You're a potato - yes, a potato - armed to the teeth (or eyes?), fighting against hordes of aliens. The beauty lies in its simplicity. It's a game that welcomes you with open arms, regardless of your skill level.

What sets Brotato apart is how it makes failure feel like progress. Each defeat is a learning curve, a step towards mastering the game. You don't just play Brotato; you evolve with it. It's the most fun I've had at failure because every setback still feels like moving forward​​.

[b]Customization and Replayability[/b]
The game shines in its customization options. With numerous traits, items, and characters, every playthrough offers a new strategy, a fresh challenge. It's the kind of game that keeps calling you back for 'just one more round.' And with its infinite replayability, Brotato always feels like a new experience​​.

Don't expect hyper-realistic graphics; Brotato charms with its original artistic direction. The visuals are a perfect match for its whimsical nature. Furthermore, it's a game that practically runs on any device. Its low requirements mean more players can enjoy this starchy adventure without hardware limitations​​.

In an era of overpriced games, Brotato stands out with its perfect pricing. It offers incredible value for its cost, making it an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a fun, engaging game without breaking the bank​​.

[b]The Verdict[/b]
[i]Brotato is a delightful, addictive game that proves you don't need complex narratives or cutting-edge graphics to create an enjoyable gaming experience. It's a testament to the charm and appeal of indie games. Easy to pick up but hard to put down, Brotato is a game that resonates with the child in all of us, reminding us that sometimes, the simplest things can bring the most joy.[/i]

[b]Key Highlights:[/b]
[list]
[*]Engaging and simple gameplay suitable for all skill levels.
[*]High replayability with various customization options.
[*]Progressive challenge that makes failure feel like an achievement.
[*]Unique and charming visual style.
[*]Affordable price with exceptional value.
[*]Runs smoothly on low-spec devices.
[/list]

This is easily one of the best games I've ever played, and definitely the best of this style of game. I feel like I'm ripping this developer off.  Everyone should drop $5 and give this a try.

"Brotato" - the game where you're a potato... with guns. Lots of guns. Honestly, when I first saw this game, I thought, "Sure, why not? My gaming life was clearly missing a gun-toting potato." Developed and published by Blobfish, "Brotato" is a top-down arena shooter roguelite that's as absurd as it sounds, yet surprisingly addictive.

The premise is simple: you're a potato - not just any potato, but Brotato. Crashed on an alien planet, you must fend off hordes of aliens with up to six weapons simultaneously. Because why settle for one gun when you can have six? The gameplay is fast-paced and chaotic, perfect for when you want to unwind by shooting extraterrestrial creatures as a starchy tuber.

The variety of traits, items, and weapons is impressive. From flamethrowers to SMGs, the arsenal is as ridiculous as the concept. Each run is unique, and customizing Brotato with different combinations of weapons and traits never gets old. The game's fast runs and waves of enemies provide a quick and satisfying play session, perfect for those short gaming breaks.

Visually, the game is simple yet effective. The top-down view works well for the bullet-hell chaos that ensues, and the designs are charming in a "potato fighting for survival" kind of way. The controls are responsive, which is crucial when you're trying to juggle six weapons while dodging alien attacks.

"Brotato" is one of those games where you think, "Who comes up with this stuff?" But then you find yourself hours deep into playing, fully invested in your potato's survival. The game's accessibility options are a nice touch, allowing you to tweak difficulty settings to your liking.

In summary, "Brotato" is absurd, fun, and surprisingly engaging. It's not going to win awards for deep storytelling or groundbreaking graphics, but that's not the point. It's a game about a potato with guns - and sometimes, that's exactly what you need. If you're looking for a quirky, fun shooter with plenty of replayability, "Brotato" is definitely worth checking out.

I think it's a good and fun game in the horde survival / action roguelite or roguelike genre. The sounds are quite satisfying and the game has a nice flow. There's a sort of meta-progression that unlocks more items to choose from when you level up.

However, the game is quite RNG-heavy, especially at higher difficulties. I will admit that I'm no expert and probably of a pretty average skill level, so take this with a grain of salt. I'd really like to see an option to "banish" certain items during the runs, since you are always looking for ONE specific weapon or sometimes you need ONE specific stat and if you do not get it you are usually sh*t out of luck.

All things considered, I recommend this game, especially considering the low price.

This is one of those games I'd review as "neutral" if I could. The game is good, but not as good as I see other reviewers claiming it to be. Of course, it might be just me.

It didn't hook me like Vampire Survivals or other similar games. I feel like a lot of people have menioned lots of pros, I'll mention a few of mine, following what bothered me.

[h3]Pros[/h3]
- The game is aesthetically pleasing. Weapons and items show up in your "brotato" which is kinda nice.
- Items and weapons seems to be very varied. I didn't see everything, but what I saw was really cool

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- Although I said the game is pretty, there seems to be only one map and I don't like how it looks. It's always a small arena (if that changes later, I don't know). I disliked this concept.
- Also, the "brotatoes" are basically the same dude with a slightly different look.
- It is wave based in a small arena. Not a fan.
- Soundtrack feels too simple and repetitive.

While on the surface, it looks like a simple clone of a million other Vampire Survivor clones, Brotato has some incredible completionist depth to explore.  The sheer volume of stats, characters, weapons, items, unlocks, and play-styles is... impressive.  This is a build-crafter's dream, with MANY more item combinations being viable than in, say, VS.

I'm currently at 38 hours as of review time, and *easily* have that many to go.  Rounds are fast, challenging, and a perfect casual roguelite.

Highly recommend!

Brotato is a top-down arena shooter roguelite that has you controlling a potato wielding up to 6 weapons at a time to fight off hordes of aliens. The content and variety are impressive, with a wide range of weapons, enemies, playable characters and difficulty levels to explore. The game is well-optimized for various systems, also featuring high-quality visuals and sound, with crisp graphics and an enjoyable soundtrack.

In conclusion, I highly recommend Brotato for those looking for a fun and challenging top-down arena shooter. Don't hesitate to give this game a try!

I picked it up when I was looking for some random game to fill the void between several bigger games, just for a couple of hours. 37 hours later, I'm still not satisfied!

On the first glance, it's just another Vampire Survivors clone. That's not a bad thing in itself, but nothing to write home about. Although, 5 minutes in you understand that it has a pinch of Binding of Isaac and something like Risk of Rain mixed in. Still nothing extremely original, but it somehow works. Boom - it's several hours later, you experiment with different builds and explore neat changes that every new character brings. And while sometimes you notice that your runs may become a bit similar - most of the time there's still more options to try.

You build your character with a combination of weapons and passive items. They have both obvious and tricky synergies between them. Shop mechanics and in-game economy allow you to have an actual BUILD, even when you are playing a limited 20-wave mode. And while your wilder ideas may never take off (I haven't managed to build a 12-stick multitasker yet), you always have a choice, you always have something to expand on and risk bulking up more power in expense of your defence and healing. Or vice versa, if you're THAT kind of player.

Right now I'm finishing up my runs with all the characters that are left (honestly, not the most entertaining ones) and planning to challenge myself for some crazy Endless runs. And planning to play a game AFTER beating it to 100% achievements is not a thing I often do ;)

Brotato is such a great game. It has both simplicity and the ability to be complex and challenging at the same time. If you just want to play a mindless game just play on a lower difficulty or play a strong character. If you want a challenge, play a difficult character or pick a difficult loadout.

In the pixelated realm where potatoes scream,
Brotato emerges, a chaotic dream.
Crafted by Blobfish, a gaming affair,
Switch it on, and you'll tear out your hair.

Early access days, a taste of the brawl,
Weapons, characters, items, and all.
New horizons expand with the full release,
Brotato's chaos, a gaming feast.

Turrets ablaze, creatures in your path,
A manic arena, a relentless wrath.
Dodging, weaving, an endless spree,
What the heck is happening in Brotato, can't you see?

Story's lacking, a bit of a miss,
But create your own in this pixel abyss.
Pick your potato hero, enter the ring,
Survive the waves, and oh, how they sting.

XP and gold, the currency of might,
Level up, choose weapons, ready for the fight.
Melee or lasers, a tactical dance,
Pros and cons, a game of chance.

Items galore, a strategic array,
Boost your stats, change the play.
Agility, speed, armor, and more,
A super vegetable hero, a unique lore.

Potatoes made pretty, a visual delight,
Brotato shines, a gaming highlight.
Audio rattles, a symphony of sound,
Slaying creatures with each bound.

Steam Deck verified, smooth as can be,
Controls buttery, for you and me.
Replay value, longevity in its stride,
Brotato's allure, a thrilling ride.

In the hot genre, it takes its stand,
Nearly perfect, a game in demand.
A minor gripe, a muddy creek,
But Brotato's charm, it truly peaks.

Defeat the bosses, survive each wave,
Elite monsters, a challenge to brave.
Gargantuan creatures, in pixels they dwell,
Brotato's potential, a tale to tell.

My wife and I take turns playing this on the deck at night.  It's wonderfully done, there are super easy chill run guaranteed characters (at low difficulties) and there are some very technical higher skill ceiling characters.  Difficulty ranges from level 0, where my mom could make it to the end boss, and almost survived it (with me picking out weapons and upgrades) and she has neverplayed a game of the type (or nearly any type besides number puzzle games), to difficulty 5, where a victory is (almost) never guaranteed.

Runs take about ten to twenty minutes, enemy variety scales up with difficulty, unlocks abound in plenty, the learning curve is low and the ceiling is decently high.

And it's amazing on the steam deck.

Initially I loved this game, but as time went on I started becoming more and more aware of the degree to which it implements casino-like, slot machine mechanics that tickle the brain's reward center and otherwise have absolutely no depth or meaning. To me, it seems like all the Vampire Survivor like games are doing this. The game poisoned the well, so to speak. And all of these slot machine games sell extremely well, which is extremely depression.

There is tons of emerging literature in neuropsychology suggesting that the casino-like mechanics heavily implemented in this game are toxic to brain's reward circuitry. I hope that it's just a matter of time before our culture wakes up to how damaging these sorts of games are, and then playing them will become taboo, just like how smoking became taboo.

I really wanted to love Brotato. The concept is cool, but the game is frustrating. First, I always feel you get too much trade off than gain when you get a new item. Also, the map is empty, the waves are very repetitive and it lacks variety if you compare to games like Vampire Survivors with its secrets/unlocks/maps or Halls Of Torment with its gears/accessories. There's a saturation of roguelite/bullet hell games and Brotato offers too little to be unique. Hell, I prefer Holocure, which is free, than this game.

Brotato blends elements of roguelike, bullet hell, and twin-stick shooter genres into a captivating experience. Players can unlock and choose from a variety of characters, each with unique strengths, and weaknesses. Experimenting with different builds adds strategic layers to the gameplay, as finding the perfect combination becomes a thrilling quest for optimization.

The game's relative simplicity may be a double-edged sword for some players. While the straightforward mechanics make it accessible to a broad audience, those seeking more intricate systems or a narrative-driven experience might find the game lacking in depth.

With the addictive nature of its gameplay, players can easily sink hours into mastering the mechanics and unlocking various character builds. The replayability factor, coupled with the challenging difficulty, ensures that the game provides excellent value for its price.

While this game might appear to be a mindless grind, it is not. It requires pretty careful character building and balancing, and sometimes luck is super important as well.
What makes it substantially different from VS is its pacing. Sure there are a lot of similarities in concepts, yet this game has its own unique highlights. I have no regret making the purchase, and it is well worth it under $5. (Actually the only regret might be that I, once in a while, feel that I am too addicted to this game sometimes. I spent 7+ hours over just two days after buying it)
[strike]Also, it is a very valuable lesson for me about prudence, especially when budgeting and balancing all the stats. I have truly regretted impulse buying on numerous occasions thus far. [/strike]

p.s. Steam Deck support is superb. I feel fortunate for being able to purchase a bugless game that can run smoothly at 60fps with both steam deck and my pc in 2023 /s

It's a really good game which is updated and balanced frequently (so far at least). And considering i spent 5€ on a game I played for 130 hours and probably will continue to play in the future, it's definitely worth the price. 

My only criticism is that on the highest difficulty some characters feel WAY HARDER than others, making them feel kinda bad to play. Especially the Saver feels kinda bad compared to others, as its gimmick (the piggy bank), feels a bit weak considering you are likely to get it on any other character at the point or shortly after you are even strong enough to use it efficiently, which leads to the character falling further behind due to the 50% increase to item price being way more impactful than the upside of 1% damage for 25 material you are currently holding and the 15 harvesting you start with, which just leads to a weaker run compared to all other characters and therefore feels more like a challenge than a unique character. 
Then again a few of the newer characters are WAY EASIER especially the Cryptid which in turn is equally as unfun as you are essentially handed a run for free and therefore does not feel fulfilling to play.

In conclusion 2 out of 44 Characters respectively aren't fun to me, meaning I roughly enjoyed 95,5% of the time I spent playing through all the characters on the highest difficulty initially, as well as all of the time I spent trying out fun builds or playing random runs with random starting weapons afterwards.

Brotato is the game you need if you feel like a hopeless psychopath. In this game, you can shoot aliens with six weapons at the same time as a potato. It's so absurd that you can't help but have fun.

So if you're having a bad day again, play Brotato. It will cleanse your soul and put a smile back on your face.

But be careful: if you play too much Brotato, you could run the risk of becoming a potato shooter junkie. Then all you'll be able to think about is how you can shoot aliens as a potato with six weapons at the same time.

But hey, that's not so bad. After all, Brotato is a damn good game.

The game is nearly good. Sadly, it's yet another "overwhelmingly positive" game that I'm giving the thumbs down to. The balance in the later difficulties feels completely out of whack with the number and strength of enemies. I'll compare some key points of Brotato with Vampire Survivors and Disfigure:

1) In Brotato, you play in a relatively small arena. Enemies spawn directly in the arena, many times directly next to your character. In VS and Disfigure, enemies spawn off screen and filter in. As a result, you receive much more cheap frustrating damage from the enemies in this game and are much more frequently put in situations where you have no choice but to tank damage to escape being surrounded.
2) In VS and Disfigure, many enemies simply try to walk into you to deal damage. This game's enemies are more varied in their AI, but also rely much more heavily on projectiles. This would be a positive thing, except Brotato does not tone down the quantity of enemies to compensate for the variety of attacks the player will have to dodge.
3) In Brotato, you acquire most items by purchasing them in a shop. The shop has 4 slots and can be refreshed by spending currency. The items have different tiers of rarity, meaning the good items will not show up as often. Getting a good run going is significantly more difficult than VS or Disfigure, which both allow you to more consistently acquire the upgrades you want. This makes VS and Disfigure more strategy and player skill, whereas Brotato is more luck-based.

Overall, Brotato feels like a game designed for you to lose repeatedly until you get lucky in the shop and have it give you the items and weapons you need. In a way it reminds me of one of my favorite games of all time: The Binding of Isaac. Except in The Binding of Isaac, your personal skill could nearly always pull you through even if the items you got were sub-par. In this game, if the shop says no, there's not much you can do about it. It feels like a transparent attempt for the game to prolong its lifespan, and it feels disrespectful.

Nevertheless, I can state with certainty that this game is spud-tacularly well-crafted and deserves a spot among the gaming gods in its genre. It's a real chip off the old block!

Brotato is a roguelite that takes the framework of Vampire Survivors, and does away with persistent upgrades to your characters in favor of an ever expanding variety in the form of new enemies / items / characters-- reminiscent of a Binding of Isaac style of progression.

It also has a different loadout system and way more stats that really get you thinking about different build types you could go for. It's neat to see build variety in a game/genre where you're only ever kiting your enemies. Well done package, very cheap. Hard to not be pleased.

It is a great example of "simple to learn, hard to master". And of "the less is more". There is simply just the core of all autoshooters survival games, but this game really does not need anything else. Small arena with clear visuals and skill based gameplay with enough different characters to keep it going for a long time. There is no meta progression that can make the game much easier, the only thing you can unlock is more characters and more items, but the core items are already there. And there is no meta stats increase or anything. If you are good enough - you can take one of the first characters and go through all 6 difficulties and it will be pretty much as easy/hard as it ever will be.
And to top it all, runs are relatively short. I did not really measure them, but I think about 20 minutes to beat the run is about it.
But if you expect any story or complicated world lore or want to grind to become more powerful - skip this game. Because none of those are here.

Very deep and addictive rougelite / auto-battler.  It's an auto-battler in the sense that your Brotato automatically aims at enemies and you upgrade / combine weapons between rounds. Its rouglite features include a range of unlockable Brotatos with unique characteristics that really switch up how runs play. It also has the loot lottery aspect of rouglites where you have equal chance of being offered a "god item" as a run-of-the-mill upgrade. It doesn't have "joke" items that cripple runs like some other rouglites but you have to be strategic with your choice of weapons and upgrades to win, particularly at higher difficulty levels. 

Overall, Brotato is great game that has a lot of depth for what looks like a simple game. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys roguelites and/or auto-battlers.

A 2D roguelike survival, delivers delightful and challenging gameplay with quirky graphics, diverse weapons, and a cool soundtrack. Easy to pick up, hard to master – it strikes the perfect balance for a fun yet engaging experience.

Got it after the Uber vid. Looked like a simple little bullet hell to enjoy

Load it up, the menu is completely uninspired, as is the opening UI. One basic fighting model. Like 4-5 enemies you'll have to learn and get used to, and the play area is just a regular square you run around in, no terrain or mix-ups on that

Lucky us! Instead of working on all that flash, the devs clearly put all that time into making the game actually feel really, REALLY good. Combat is pretty great. Tons and tons of weapons with good builds and synergies. There's like 40 characters, and they're not your typical roguelike breed where they have a few different stats and maybe start with a different weapon. The vast majority of them drastically change various mechanics in the game to force you to play to that character's strengths.

It took me about 3 hours to finally get a winning run, which was extremely satisfying. I just got my first max difficulty win 17 hours or so, with all but 1 character unlocked now. I got a lot of value out of this game, and I'm not done yet.

One thing to note is that this game is HARD, and also, it's a game of scaling. If you don't build right, you'll simply get outscaled and die from being overwhelmed by the enemies. That's just the nature of this game. It's also a lot more frustrating in that nature compared to slower paced roguelikes I liked like Gungeon and Hades - you could be having a blast until midgame hits and then a projectile hits you for half your HP and you panic. "God runs" can be over in an instant and gone forever, and you have to accept that as part of the journey. Also, I'm a noob, but I've only found one specific type of playstyle to really work for me, I keep getting clapped with any variation from it. None of these are gripes - in fact, probably my only gripe for this game is what appears to be a severe lack of RNG manip to get the builds you want. I think there's /some/, and wikis might have the answers to this, but I'm not one to just reset until I get a good start. I'd like a bit more control over what I build and buy.

But these devs are the antithesis of greed. Right on that boring landing page is a Mods button. There are also difficulty sliders in the options. I'd recommend, especially if you're struggling or new to roguelikes and bullet hells, to just crank the HP and damage to the bottom while keeping speed normal so you can learn the pace of the game in a less punishing manner. Crank them both back up a bit after every win! All in all, this is an INSANE value add to any steam library, I'll probably be gifting it to a few friends for the holidays this year, and I'm stoked to go and play with mods now that I've "beaten" the core game.

Well, I'm not sure what else I can say that I bought this game because I wanted another one of these auto-shooters or reverse bullet-hell games, and then I suddenly blinked back to life and found myself having played it for almost 9 hours. 

Upsides: Lots of different fun weapons and strategies, a lot of different characters to unlock with lots of different difficulties for each, and it lets you somewhat build your own runs rather than just hoping you'll get something good at some point. 

Downsides: Not a huge fan of the art style or how bland and boring the map is. Lots of the same colors on every single enemy and the battlefield is just a boring square.

Overall, for five bucks, it's got a lot of content to blast through when you want a game to listen to podcasts while playing or have some youtube videos running in the background. Not bad at all.

The potato is a starchy root vegetable native to the Americas that is consumed as a staple food in many parts of the world. Potatoes are tubers of the plant Solanum tuberosum, a perennial in the nightshade family Solanaceae.

Wild potato species can be found from the southern United States to southern Chile. The potato was originally believed to have been domesticated by Native Americans independently in multiple locations, but later genetic studies traced a single origin, in the area of present-day southern Peru and extreme northwestern Bolivia. Potatoes were domesticated there approximately 7,000–10,000 years ago, from a species in the S. brevicaule complex. In the Andes region of South America, where the species is indigenous, some close relatives of the potato are cultivated.

Potatoes were introduced to Europe from the Americas by the Spanish in the second half of the 16th century. Potatoes are a staple food in many parts of the world and an integral part of much of the world's food supply. Following millennia of selective breeding, there are now over 5,000 different types of potatoes. Over 99% of potatoes presently cultivated worldwide descend from varieties that originated in the lowlands of south-central Chile. The importance of the potato as a food source and culinary ingredient varies by region and is still changing. It remains an essential crop in Europe, especially Northern and Eastern Europe, where per capita production is still the highest in the world, while the most rapid expansion in production during the 21st century was in southern and eastern Asia, with China and India leading the world production of 376 million tonnes (370,000,000 long tons; 414,000,000 short tons), as of 2021.

Like the tomato, the potato is a nightshade in the genus Solanum, and the vegetative and fruiting parts of the potato contain the toxin solanine which is dangerous for human consumption. Normal potato tubers that have been grown and stored properly produce glycoalkaloids in negligible amounts, but, if green sections of the plant (namely sprouts and skins) are exposed to light, the tuber can accumulate a high enough concentration of glycoalkaloids to affect human health.

This game seems super simple on the surface, but as you spend more time in it, you'll come to realise that it's actually a very well-designed shmup.  Brotato boasts 49 unique characters and each of them demands that the player adopts a unique play-style to fully realise their potential.

It took me 87 hours to beat every character in the game on Danger 5.  It's an addictive grind as the character selection screen will colour the background of each character with the corresponding colour of the highest danger level you've completed with said character.  The goal of painting the character screen gold becomes quickly apparent as you start to knock over your favourite characters one-by-one.

Fast forward a week or two, now you've completed Danger 5 on about 15-20 characters and as you look at the remainder of the roster, you start to wonder just how in the hell you're going to complete a run on any of them.  This is honestly why I had so much fun playing this game, the characters I wasn't comfortable with truly challenged me and had me on the edge of my seat as I beat the final boss wave to ultimately paint them gold on the character screen.

This game is best played with a controller if you have one.  I'd happily recommend this game to any completionist looking for a fun and unique challenge.

Brotato: The Spudtacular Roguelike Adventure

Have you ever wondered if a potato could rule the universe? Wonder no more! Brotato is a game that answers that question with a resounding 'Yes!' This game is so simple, you could play it one-handed while making a sandwich with the other. Yet, it's addictively complex in its own right.

The premise is simple: you start with a humble potato, barely more than a starchy lump with dreams. From there, you embark on a journey of epic proportions, transforming this unassuming tuber into a god of destruction. The game's rogue-like nature means each playthrough is a new adventure, with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on your toes—or rather, on your one free hand.

But don't let the game's simplicity fool you. The strategic depth is astounding. You'll find yourself weighing the pros and cons of various upgrades and weapons, from the classic 'Fry Slicer' to the awe-inspiring 'Mashinator 3000'. Each choice shapes your potato into a unique force of nature, capable of taking down hordes of enemies with ease.

The best part? Brotato is as cheap as chips! It offers enormous value for its price, providing hours of entertainment without breaking the bank. So, if you're looking for a game that combines humor, strategy, and the chance to see a potato wield nunchucks, Brotato is your go-to game. It's a root-vegetable rampage that you won't want to miss!

🥔🚀 Hello, fellow space farmers and intergalactic spud enthusiasts! Fasten your asteroid belts, because we're about to embark on a comedic odyssey in 'Brotato,' a game where a potato takes on the universe. Yes, you heard it right – it's carb-loading with a cosmic twist!

👾🌌 Imagine a universe where potatoes are not just for eating. In Brotato, you're a lone spud against an array of bizarre aliens. It's like 'Space Invaders,' but your spaceship is a potato, and your weapons are... also pretty much potato-based. The starch wars have begun!

🔫🥔 The arsenal? Oh, it's a root vegetable's dream. From fry-cutters to mashed-potato cannons, your weaponry is as innovative as it is absurd. It's like MacGyver met Mr. Potato Head, and they decided to save the galaxy.

🌟👽 Every alien you meet is more eccentric than the last. One moment you're blasting a space carrot, the next, you're dodging angry space broccoli. It's like a galactic farmer's market gone wild. And yes, the jokes about 'salad days' are endless.

🛸🥗 Customization in Brotato is a blast. You can deck out your spud in the finest space armor (which suspiciously looks like kitchen utensils). It's like playing dress-up, if dress-up involved gearing up to take down extraterrestrial eggplants.

🤣💥 In conclusion, 'Brotato' is a delightful blend of humor and space action. It's a game that teaches us valuable lessons: never underestimate a potato, and in space, everyone can hear you fry.

🌟🌟🌟🌟½: 4.5/5 stars for this spud-tacular space adventure. If you're looking for a game that's both action-packed and a total hoot, 'Brotato' is your ticket to the stars!

Absolutely incredible. Tonnes of characters and each one feels unique. Multiple difficulties to progress through. Cool unlock system. Very fun to play.
I also want to applaud the accessibility settings. I don't play games to be frustrated. So when I saw that I was enjoying the gameplay, but struggling a bit, I turned enemy health and damage down to 50%. The game is still challenging but it is now catered to the experience I want to have. Plus all the unlocks and achievements still work. Never be ashamed to lower the difficulty. Games are supposed to be fun.
Now we get to the workshop and community. So much additional fan created content. The only problem is that I have so many mods that half my runs now crash before the end due to incompatibility between mods. But that's an issue that I created, and can't blame the game at all.
After over 200hrs in the game, I had to force myself to walk away because I wanted to experience other games in this genre, but i will be back to see what new mods people have made during my absence.

overhyped and not fun.

I can only guess some streamers played this to an audience that had never seen halls of torment or vampire survivors. I saw a review that praised it a lot, bought it and oh boy do I feel duped.
it's clear the guy had no idea what other games in the genre do already. and how stupidly sweaty the game is.
I played for one hour and already got 2 achievements that only a bit over 40% of people had. if I play ANY game in this genre I own, I never get anything that not already 80-90% of people have.

this tells me normies who are impressed with the genre gave it rave reviews, but stopped playing immediately. many such cases... 
it's hard for the sake of being hard. and there is no meta progression that "gets you further". there is the lamest unlocks you can imagine, i.e. completely gimped or amputated alternative potato guys you can play. some are decent. but there's nothing you unlock that gives you ANY feeling of progression or unlocking more of the game.

it's the complete opposite of Halls of Torment or the excellent new "God of Weapons" with myriad unlocks, classes, subclasses, weapons and items you can unlock or earn though challenges.

this game is trash in comparison. it has a lot of things you can find each round, but it's so sweaty that you feel you have to give it 100% all the time or just die.
that's fine, if I can find ways to grind my way to getting farther, but you can't. that's it, boy, that's the game.

it's basically a highscore type of experience, sans any high score because the game does not save your runs. now get back and do the round! "why?" "JUST DO IT!"

I did almost all achievements in the pretty challenging Halls of Torment or Vampire survivors (it has new ones now I don't have yet) without ever asking myself "why"... here, I played 1-2h with some alt-tabbing and I feel I'm sick of the game.
I feel zero interest in playing. why? well... I've seen the whole game. there is nothing else.

no maps, unlocks, weapons I haven't seen. sure I have not used *all* weapons, but I've used a lot to test them out, and I barely see any difference. they don't feel unique or fun.

Halls of Torment has insanely unique and different classes and weapons/spells. this is just visual noise.

and the game is pretty unfair at times. it has this obsession with cheap shots, like old coin machine games that made more money when they put you in no-win situations or spawned some boss on you with an attack you can't possibly evade unless you know already from where exactly it will come...

that's how this game feels. you routinely get zero chance of finding something that makes you survive the round.

when I die in vampire survivors, halls of torment or god of weapons, it's my fault. every time. I made a mistake. and usually I know pretty well what I did wrong.
not here. it's pretty much always the game's fault and conversely, if I survive, it feels like it's also the game's "fault". it's like playing a slot machine. you really don't have any impact. and most people agree with me. otherwise I'd not have unlocked so many achievements that the majority of people don't have after just 1h playtime.

there is a lot of delusional "skill issue" memers in the comments preventing any course correction in this trash heap of a game. 
a lot of games like this have this crowd that never plays, but hangs out in the comments to lord over people who complain that it's unfairly designed or wanna-be hard just for no reason with no goal you can get to.

Halls of Torment is *a lot harder* when you start at zero with no unlocks, a hell of a lot harder especially in the second map with a fresh character. but I loved that there because I knew getting to it would get me some reward that would make me stronger.

in this game, if I get through it does not depend on my skills. and when I do get through, I get nothing from it.

An awesome take on the survivor genre. While I liked vampire survivors, I honestly enjoyed Brotato even more. I especially appreciate the round-based format (rather than one continuous match). There is also less ambiguity about the play-style of each character. You also get to choose from many, many upgrades, and there's a bit more challenge than other survivor games with the dodging necessary. Not surprisingly, this runs awesome on Steam Deck, easily hit 90fps if you have the OLED model, and of course, battery life is good, too. All in all, you can't go wrong with Brotato, it's an awesome time for anyone who enjoys this genre, especially at such a steal of a price.

An incredibly addictive survival roguelite, I would close it in frustration after incredibly lucky run gone bad and then some minutes later I'd launch it again trying another build and approach, quickly racking up a day worth of playtime.

This one has you running in a limited arena, dodging enemies spawning periodically, taking them down to collect dropped resources in short, mostly 60 second rounds, a total of 20 in a regular game. Between these rounds you pick level up upgrades and buy up items and weapons. It's a very simple loop, with short hectic rounds, and purchasing as thoughtful as you want it to be.

The most hooking part in all this? It's very fun to create and try out entirely different builds. There's a variety of characters to unlock by playing, each offering very distinct ways to play, giving bonuses in exchange for some playstyle or progression limitations. Like one rewards you for keeping enemies alive at end of life while dodging them, another one strongly restricts all ways of restoring health apart from food pickups that drop across level. Then there's weapons. Some characters have restrictions or additions but mostly everyone gets max six each, firing or swinging at closest enemy. Apart from damage outputs and trajectories, there's varied utility effects like improving player regeneration, adding permanent stats for sufficient kills trough a round, etc. And then there's stats and items you buy. See, there's just always at least a couple interesting interactions between those, especially in the second apart of game when you secure rarer artifacts with special bonuses like "one extra damage for each speed bonus" - and beyond lower difficulties it's crucial to find a tactic that helps scale the stats to keep up with enemies and give you an edge in survival. Also many items you buy come with a drawback that adds additional nuance - like one critical chance increasing item also slightly drops damage, but is that a big deal when you're focusing on critical chance effects of your weapons?

Only thing I dislike is that it's rather bit... granular. Way too many +1% to +5% tweaks. Sure you stock up a whole bunch of these per run but it's a far cry from how it feels to get a new powerful item in other Surviors-likes. Also I guess depending on build the screen can get very overwhelmed with stuff. Not as much as many other of these games, mind, but space here is very limited so it feels so much more tight. Also wish there was more music. The soundtrack works surprisingly well but there aren't that many tracks there.

I totally recommend this one if you enjoy experimenting with stats and builds, goes real cheap and yet is extremely gripping.

Brotato is a bullet heaven/survivor-like that differentiates itself from other games in the genre by focusing on character classes to make runs unique and randomised shopping to bring variance and difficulty.

Gameplay in Brotato is simple: pick a class, pick a weapon, enter a small arena, and run for your life as your weapons automatically attack the enemies around you. As you kill enemies you'll gain both experience and money. Experience is used to level you up, allowing you to select randomised power increases. Money is used between rounds to purchase new weapons and passive items from a shop. Items range from very common (and very boring) to rare, interesting, and synergistic. Assembling a selection of interesting items that work together often takes several runs and some experimenting, but it's satisfying when it happens.

More than items, classes are what make Brotato unique. When starting a run you can choose which character class you'd like to play as, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. There are several dozen classes to choose from (unlocking as you play and win) and each is very unique and forces you to make different choices in both play-style and item selection. There are also 5 difficulty levels, and attempting to beat the hardest difficulty with each class requires high knowledge of the game and a fair amount of luck.

These two paths, items and classes, make Brotato a lot more interesting for a lot longer than most bullet heaven games, which usually devolve into very samey gameplay with few choices after a few repetitions. I was actively involved for the entire time I was unlocking new classes to play as, and it was always interesting to play within the strengths and weaknesses of said classes.

On the negative side, there are some issues of balance. Melee-focused classes and weapons are often at a strong disadvantage, given that it's more dangerous to be close to an enemy than far away. This isn't unusual in action games, but it could have been more strongly compensated for in class and weapon stats. There's also the usual bullet heaven problem: once you're ahead you stay ahead, because you're killing and gaining money and experience faster than the game is giving you enemies; and once you're behind you're staying behind, because there is no catch-up mechanic. These aren't large enough issues to ruin the fun of the game, but you'll absolutely notice them if you play for long enough.

All told, Brotato is an exercise in pure gameplay. It has enough variance in both classes and items to continue to be fun after many, many hours of play, and it's more interesting than most games in its newly-emerging genre. There's also an active mod community, allowing for many more hours of fun. I strongly recommend it.

Really fun and chill game; my favorite part personally was watching as the blood of my enemies splattered as I maniacally gun them down with 6 level IV mini-guns, seeing them move towards me knowing full well they are only on a pathway of which the final destination of that of their creator. To see as we dance to this cruel tango over and over again we call death. Maybe it's all a metaphor for the greater evil that lies inside of us all, that we only dare to project onto others around us to make us feel more secure and reassured of our own actions, or maybe it means nothing at all... Doesn't it always?

Despite the game not having much more than its single-player and endless mode, Brotato is capable of being can't-put-down fun. Thanks to quick rounds, accessible controls, and easy upgrade options, each run has the potential to be intense and memorable. Still, Brotato's adorably violent art style and characters are begging to be more thoroughly fleshed out with lore. 

The game would also be a blast on handheld or mobile devices, and with a multiplayer mode where friends could join their spuds together in chaotic cooperative combat. Still, Blobfish has proven itself with Brotato, a really fun action game that stars a six-weapon-wielding potato who fights alien hordes.

My kids when they first saw the game, thought the graphics were a bit retro but don't let that fool you as that's part of the charm. You get sucked into trying to survive the increasingly difficult waves of mobs while gearing up your spud. This is easily a recommend!

Give a potato 6 weapons and fight through 20 waves of enemies.

That's Brotato, at least the basis of it. There are really loads of playable Brotato, weapons and various items to survive these waves with different stats and strategies. And the characters are not even 100% committed to one strategy, experiments are allowed in the game and depending on how it is built, the game rewards you with a sense of achievement. 

Even when I bought it, I didn't think I would get more than 100 hours of gameplay, but this game is so versatile, yet relatively simple in concept.

For those of you who enjoy playing this type of game, Brotato is an absolute must!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories...

Another game in the Survivors genre, but it's not a clone.  Brotato has several things which help it to stand out from the crowd.

First, and most obvious (as well as least-significant) is the graphics.  When I first saw what the game looked like, it turned me off a bit; too cartoony / goofy.  Nonetheless, the silliness works here, because after a few sweaty minutes of trying not to die, you realize that where a mob used to look goofy, it now looks dangerous.  I quickly stopped caring about the cartoony nature of the game, and sorta learned to love it as unique.

Second, the game is faster-paced than its peers, and this requires twitch skills most of the other Survivors games lack.  Yes, true to the game genre, you're still just running around to pick things up or avoid them.  There's very little aiming to be done.  And yet the pace of the game is pretty frantic at times.  This keeps it entertaining.

Thirdly, there's more bullet hell in Brotato than I've seen in many of the other Survivors games.  Rather than the screen being swamped with mobs, it's a mess of mobs AND bullets - and some of the latter can be beneficial.  I like being forced to recognize between stuff that has to be avoided, and stuff you want to get closer to.  Similarly, some of the mobs have to die *fast* because they're dangerous, so you'll find yourself choosing when to charge and when to run away.

One last thing I've noticed (which makes this game stand out) is the length of a run.  In the first couple of difficulty levels, each run contains 20 "maps", and each only takes a few minutes to beat.  This keeps the frantic pace from tiring you out too much; you can go nuts for 10-15 minutes, and then pause between maps.

There are lots of other details, but the bottom line is that Brotato is a SOLID competitor to other games in the genre.  Don't be fooled by the graphics: it's seriously challenging in all the right ways.

[h3]💬 Comments 💬[/h3]
[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
Brotato is a roguelite bullet hell game where players are attacked through twenty waves by different types of aliens and must upgrade their character on each run to become stronger and survive.
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, firstly, the gameplay is quite entertaining, featuring a wide variety of unique characters, different difficulty settings, and a diverse selection of weapons that offer many challenges to overcome. Secondly, the roguelite aspect is decent, with numerous stats that are each important, allowing for various winning strategies. Additionally, the weapons are well-balanced, and you will find yourself utilizing most of the available arsenal.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, the main drawback is the limited number of bosses and the repetition of the same aliens throughout all the waves. This lack of monster variation, coupled with the fact that each weapon tier looks identical, can make the gameplay feel monotonous. Improving this aspect would add more liveliness to the game. Additionally, the roguelite system has its flaws, as even after unlocking new items in the shop, the same items tend to appear repeatedly, leading to repetitive runs that rely heavily on random number generation (RNG) rather than player skill.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
In conclusion, Brotato is a decent roguelite bullet hell game with numerous challenges. However, it falls short in terms of repetition, and adding more content would greatly enhance its overall appeal. I would rate the game a 7.25/10.

Brotato is one of the most creative roguelike games I've ever played. Like I said in some of my other reviews, creativity runs in this game genre. Brotato manages to take it to another extreme entirely, to combine the game loop of a classic like Vampire Survivors and turn it into something else.

Each round is very short, but still exhilarating alike. The action never gets boring, and even  though I've put over 300 hours into this game, I still catch myself longing to play Brotato. A while back, I tried to quit, but couldn't. The gameplay loop just encaptures this feeling of one more round, one more attempt, that I hadn't felt in a while. The last game that truly hooked me like that was Slay the Spire, though I'd argue Brotato reeled me in way harder.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: This review is/was written when this game was in/is still in Early Access. Think twice before buying/playing this game [/quote]

Brotato is a game developed and published by Blobfish

The game offers some nice graphics and environments, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same and has a really great aesthetic

For an Early Access game and in it's current state, it already offers so much content that other games in the Early Access phase pale in comparison, so props to the developer for offering so much content and constantly adding more

Brotato overall, however, is a fun game to play, and it does get boring if being played for a long time, but is a great action roguelike, bullet hell game and to play in short bursts

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

De los Vampire Survivors-like (dale, convengamos de una vez en llamarlos Bullet Heaven y zanjada la cuestión) es uno de los más originales, y el más dinámico. Las partidas son cortas, y están divididas en 20 olas con un final boss, y al final de cada ola podemos comprar items con la moneda acumulada. Los gráficos pueden no parecer los más lindos al principio pero uno le va tomando cariño. El movimiento es ágil y la jugabilidad frenética. Tiene más de 30 personajes para desbloquear, todos con características muy diferentes entre sí que cambian la manera en la que uno planea las run: elegir diferentes items o priorizar distintas stats. Tiene mucha rejugabilidad con 5 niveles de dificultad para cada personaje, y muchos items desbloqueables. Ojalá sigan agregándole contenido, porque es un juego que engancha muy fácil y es ideal para rellenar esos ratitos libres que uno tiene a veces.

[b]Brotato[/b], probably [b]the[/b] meme game of 2022, is a fantastic 2D action roguelike like Vampire Survivors or 20 Minutes till Dawn. This time around you don't have to aim as your weapons (max 6!) autoaim and you just have to move around the enemy waves and collect materials. This game features an insane amount of weapons, skills, secondary buffs, enemies, characters ("potatos") and builds! If you want to try one of the most popular action roguelikes from 2022 i would recommend this one. And it still gets updates!

[h1]"Fast-Paced Fun with Impressive Variety - A Brotato Review"[/h1]

If you're looking for a game that's easy to dive into for a quick burst of fun but equally simple to put down, "Brotato" is a perfect choice. This isn't just another shooter game; it's a compact package of exhilaration that keeps calling you back for more. Here's why I highly recommend it:

Perfect for Quick Sessions: One of the best things about "Brotato" is how it fits into any schedule. Whether you have a few minutes to spare or an hour, this game provides an immediately satisfying experience without the need for long-term commitment. Jump in, blast some aliens, and step out whenever you need to - it's as simple as that.

Diverse Character Roster: The variety of characters in "Brotato" is truly impressive. Each character brings its own unique playstyle, making the gameplay feel fresh and exciting every time. This diversity ensures that players can continually experiment and find new ways to enjoy the game, catering to all types of gamers.

Endless Build Possibilities: "Brotato" truly shines in its build variety. The joy of experimenting with different builds, tweaking your strategy, and seeing the results is a core part of the game's appeal. It's thrilling to mix and match abilities and weapons to create the perfect alien-fighting machine.

Simple Yet Clever Design: Developed using the Godot Engine, "Brotato" stands out with its straightforward yet ingenious design. It's a testament to how a game doesn't need complex graphics to be engaging. The simplicity of the design paired with smart gameplay mechanics makes "Brotato" a standout indie game.

In conclusion, "Brotato" is a gem of a game that's easy to pick up but hard to put down. Its blend of simplicity, variety, and replayability makes it a must-try for anyone who enjoys a good shooter with a twist. Definitely, a game worth adding to your collection!

Brotato is a top-down arena shooter roguelite where you play a potato wielding up to 6 weapons at a time to fight off hordes of aliens. The game is simple to learn but difficult to master, with a wide variety of weapons, traits, and items to choose from that allow you to create unique builds.

The core gameplay loop is very addictive. Each run starts with you spawning in an arena with a few basic weapons and some currency. You then need to fight your way through a series of waves of enemies, collecting currency and picking up new weapons, traits, and items as you go. Once you reach the end of the 20th wave, you'll face a boss. If you defeat the boss, you'll win the run.

If you die, you'll start over from the beginning, but you'll keep any currency or items that you've unlocked. This allows you to gradually improve your character over time, making it easier to progress further in each run.

The game is also very visually appealing, with a simple but stylish art style. The music is also great, and it really helps to get you pumped up for each run.

Overall, Brotato is a great game that's perfect for fans of roguelikes and top-down shooters. It's simple to learn but difficult to master, with a wide variety of content to keep you coming back for more. I highly recommend it.

Here are some tips and tricks for you if you want to try:
-Character Choice: Try a ranged character like the ranger for effective gameplay.
-Beta Branch: Play on the beta branch under Steam preferences, as the boss is easier and less buggy there.
-Defense Strategy: Focus on acquiring a lot of defenses like HP, Armor, and Healing, allowing room for mistakes.
-Shopping Strategy: Avoid buying small gains unless they're cheap. Stick to your plan, and prioritize rare weapons for better value and power increase.
-Luck Factor: Focus on Luck early in the game. Luck in the initial turns (1-5) will significantly strengthen your run. Continue focusing on luck until about floor 10, then switch to concentrating on weapons and defense.
-Weapon Choice: Lifesteal works well with very fast weapons like SMG, Minigun, and Flamethrower. It's also effective, albeit to a lesser extent, with AOE weapons.
-Item Availability: The items you hold will appear more frequently in the store. For example, holding a wrench will result in more wrenches appearing in the store.
-Stat Prioritization: Some stats to be wary of are:
Range: It slows down melee weapon attack speed, and ranged weapons already have sufficient range.
Harvesting: Generally not worth it, except possibly very early in the game.
Engineering: Avoid dabbling in this unless you're fully committed.
Elemental: Extremely strong if fully committed, but avoid getting distracted from your main build and survival strategy

This game is like the cute and cuddly younger sibling to Vampire Survivor, meaning he appears to be a darling little angel until mom and dad aren't looking, and then you want to throw him through the drywall because of how infuriating and obnoxious he is. Yet, like any younger sibling, you only you get to hate on him, and will defend him from anyone who tries to pick on him.

I have a love/hate relationship with Brotato. On the one hand, the art style, gameplay, and easy to understand game mechanics lure you into the sense that this game will lead to a chill play sesh (+1 if you are using the Steamdeck, which it feels perfect on). On the other hand, unlike Vampire Survivor you are constrained to an arena, which makes the increasingly difficult mobs even harder to manage, and it truely feels like a bullet hell. What I like about this game over Vampire Survivor is the emphasis on creating a build using in game currency to buy items and weapons that alter stats. You may increase your damage, but now you have no armor and your speed is reduced to nothing. Every purchase is a decision that can bite you in the ass later.

Also, if you have trouble beating levels, you can adjust enemy health, speed, and damage in accessibility settings. There is no shame in it, and getting all of the unlocks is more fun than repeatedly dying over and over again, which you will do. 

10/10

I initially struggled to connect with games in the "Vampire Survivors" sub-genre, finding them mildly entertaining for about half an hour. However, Brotato managed to capture my interest more than any other game of this style. The game's unique twist, placing players in the shoes of a potato, turned out to be surprisingly engaging. The potato comes in various forms, and unlocking different characters with their own traits added a layer of depth, making each playthrough feel distinct.

I appreciated the game's adjustable difficulty, accommodating both seasoned players and newcomers. Throughout the gameplay, the progression system allowed for character enhancement and weapon upgrades, leading to a sense of accomplishment and eventual victory. Brotato proved to be a well-thought-out rogue-lite, offering a fun and casual way to pass the time without being overly complicated.

The combat mechanics were a standout feature, providing a satisfying experience with precise hit-boxes and diverse combat styles. The consistent and visually appealing art style, along with excellent sound design, contributed to an overall polished feel. The extensive variety of weapons, items, and characters demonstrated a careful balance, ensuring that each choice mattered during gameplay.

While the game had its drawbacks, such as overly easy achievements and occasional glitches, the positives outweighed the negatives. The affordability, replayability, and short run times made it a game I'd recommend, especially for those with a busy schedule. It's clear that not every game is for everyone, but Brotato managed to exceed my expectations and offered a unique and enjoyable gaming experience.
